ovenTypes.name: Conventional Oven
ovenTypes.description: Standard home oven without special pizza-making features.

round.recommended: As high as your oven can go, preferably 500°F (260°C)

generalInstructions: Preheat your oven for at least 30 minutes before baking.
For round pizzas, position the rack in the lower third of the oven.
For pan pizzas, position the rack in the middle of the oven.
Consider using a baking steel or pizza stone to enhance heat distribution.
cons: Less crispy results than specialty ovens

ovenTypes.name: Pizza Stone in Conventional Oven
ovenTypes.description: A conventional oven with a pizza stone or steel for improved heat retention and distribution.

round.recommended: 500°F (260°C) or as high as your oven can go

generalInstructions: Place pizza stone on the lowest rack of your oven.
Preheat the stone for at least 45-60 minutes before baking.
Use a pizza peel dusted with semolina or cornmeal to slide pizza onto the hot stone.
For pan pizzas, place the pan directly on the hot stone.
pros: Better crust than conventional oven alone
cons: Can be challenging to slide pizza onto stone
Still limited by oven's maximum temperature
Stone can break if not properly cared for

ovenTypes.name: Dedicated Pizza Oven
ovenTypes.description: Specialized high-temperature oven designed specifically for pizza making, often wood-fired, gas-powered, or electric.
generalInstructions: Fully heat the oven for 30-60 minutes before cooking.
For wood-fired ovens, maintain a small flame during cooking.
Rotate pizza frequently (every 20-30 seconds) for even cooking.
Keep an infrared thermometer handy to monitor surface temperatures.
For pan pizzas, use heat-resistant metal pans and position away from direct flames.

wood-fired.description: Traditional brick ovens heated by burning wood.
notes: Heat level varies throughout the dome
Requires skill to maintain proper temperature

gas.description: Modern pizza ovens powered by gas burners.

electric.description: Countertop or outdoor electric pizza ovens.

pros: Very fast cooking times (60-90 seconds for Neapolitan)
Superior texture with proper rise and crisp exterior
cons: Limited cooking space in many models
